The closest thing you can try is the XML Canonicalization algorithm, (available 
from <color><param>0100,0100,0100</param><FontFamily><param>Times New Roman</param><bigger>{HYPERLINK "http://www.w3.org/TR/2001/REC-xml-c14n-20010315"}<underline><color><param>0000,0000,FF00</param>http://www.w3.org/TR/2001/REC-xml-c14n-20010315</underline></color><FontFamily><param>Arial</param><smaller>) to compare 
the canonicalise form of teh two documents. You can find implementations of 
this canonicalization algorithm in the Apache XML-Security project as well as 
the IBM XSS4j from Alphaworks. According to the specs, the canonicalization 
algorithm may not be 100% what you want, however, as (to my understanding) 
it does not convert perfixes to the corresponding namespaces, that is, if you 
have in one document a prefix dsig for the XML signature namespace, and if 
you have in another document a prefix ds for the same namespace, 
canonicalising the documents will still not result in the two documents having 
the same prefixes.


Cheers,

Herry


Cheers,

Herry

<color><param>0100,0100,0100</param>On 11 Jan 2002, at 11:05, Magnus ?or Torfason wrote:


<color><param>7F00,0000,0000</param>> I have an XML generation process that I use to convert internal

> datastructures to XML.  I want this process to be Unit tested, to ensure

> that the generated XML matches the template XML that I have defined.

> 

> My problem is that the only way to compare the two files in a simple way is

> to do a string compare.  This is not acceptable, since I am not interested

> in string equality (encoding and linefeed may very well differ) but in XML

> equality (that both documents have exactly the same elements and

> attributes).

> 

> Does anyone know of a way to compare two XML files so that only the XML

> semantics are compared, not the underlying strings?

> 

> Thanks and regards,

> 

> Magnus Torfason

> 

>
